Kini Shah mampu dampingi bintang K-pop
07 Nov 2019, 22:00 by Redzuan Muharam
BERMULA dengan hanya mempelajari bahasa Korea di Youtube, siapa sangka Siti Aishah Noor Azham kini fasih bertutur hingga diberi kepercayaan menjadi penterjemah bagi menjayakan konsert bintang K-pop terkemuka antaranya kumpulan kesayangan ramai, Blackpink.
Kisah Siti Aishah atau lebih mesra dengan panggilan Shah itu mendapat perhatian warganet selepas gadis berusia 23 tahun itu berkongsi pengalamannya berhijrah ke Korea Selatan pada Februari 2017 sebelum pulang semula ke tanah air pada April lalu.
Perkongsian berkenaan mendapat pelbagai reaksi daripada warganet dan ramai kagum dengan kesungguhan serta semangat Shah untuk bangkit selepas kecundang dalam akademik di sekolah disebabkan masalah kesihatan.
Menceritakan latar belakangnya, Shah berkata, selepas tamat persekolahan, dia memohon untuk menyambung pengajian di universiti tetapi tidak berjaya sebelum menceburi perniagaan dengan menawarkan perkhidmatan dalam bidang rekaan grafik.
“Sejal kecil lagi, saya sering diserang migrain dan keadaan itu menyebabkan saya ketinggalan dalam pelajaran kerana cuti sakit dan akhirnya memperoleh keputusan kurang memberangsangkan dalam Sijil Pelajaran Malaysia (SPM).
“Disebabkan gagal menerima tawaran ke universiti, saya gunakan kemahiran dimiliki dengan menawarkan perkhidmatan rekaan grafik untuk baju-T dan lain-lain lagi tetapi perniagaan itu terhenti di pertengahan jalan kerana jumlah tempahan yang kurang memberangsangkan.
“Sementara menanti peluang lain tiba, saya ambil inisiatif dengan mempelajari bahasa Korea di Youtube dan tidak mengikuti kelas ketika itu kerana bayarannya yang mahal.
“Selepas enam bulan, saya ambil keputusan berhijrah ke Korea Selatan hanya dengan berbekalkan wang simpanan yang ada sebanyak RM700.
“Sepanjang 14 bulan berada di sana (Korea Selatan), saya menyara hidup dengan bekerja di rumah tamu dan memang mencabar kerana tiada pilihan kecuali bertutur dalam bahasa Korea untuk ‘survive ‘ (bertahan),” katanya ketika dihubungi Harian Metro.


Shah ketika berada di Korea. Foto Ihsan Siti Aishah Noor Azham

Bercerita lanjut, sebelum kembali ke tanah air, dia pernah diitawarkan menjadi penterjemah dan pembabitan sulungnya adalah dalam konsert Winner dan iKON pada tahun lalu.
Menurut Shah, tawaran itu diterima selepas seorang rakan mengusulkan namanya kepada penganjur tetapi dia tetap perlu melalui proses saringan awal.
Sekembalinya ke Malaysia, Shah berehat selama sebulan sebelum bekerja sebagai pereka grafik dan penterjemah di sebuah syarikat kosmetik Korea Selatan berpangkalan di Kuala Lumpur.
“Sehingga kini, saya masih menerima tawaran sebagai penterjemah dan walaupun berpengalaman, saya tetap perlu mengikut syarat ditetapkan penganjur iaitu menghantar ‘resume’ untuk dinilai sebelum berjaya disenarai pendek.
“Nampak menyeronokkan tetapi bukan mudah bekerja dengan orang luar kerana mereka amat teliti dan mementingkan kesempurnaan jadi saya perlu bersiap sedia dari segi mental dan fizikal.
“Kebiasaannya, konsert akan diadakan pada hujung minggu dan beberapa hari sebelumnya, saya sudah mula bertugas dengan menjadi penterjemah bagi pengarah jurutera bunyi Korea Selatan dan wakil di Malaysia.
“Setakat ini, saya tiada masalah ketika melakukan terjemahan tetapi pernah juga tersalah faham ketika berurusan dengan jurutera bunyi kerana menyangka dia bercakap mengenai teknikal sedangkan mahukan air kerana dahaga.
“Namun, pengalaman ditimba selama ini amat berharga dan tidak sangka diberi kepercayaan berurusan dengan artis dan penganjur konsert dari Korea Selatan kerana hakikatnya, saya bukanlah peminat K-pop walaupun ia menjadi kegilaan sebilangan rakyat Malaysia,” katanya yang bercadang menyambung pengajian dalam jurusan Sejarah dan Hak Asasi Manusia di Korea.

Now Shah can afford to be a K-pop star
07 Nov 2019, 22:00 by Redzuan Muharam
Starting by learning Korean on Youtube, who thought Siti Aishah Noor Azham was now fluent in speaking up to be credited as a translator for a successful K-pop star concert among her favorite band Blackpink.
The story of Siti Aishah or more as she calls Shah's attention after the 23-year-old shared her experience of emigrating to South Korea in February 2017 before returning home in April.
The partnership received a lot of reaction from the public and many were impressed by Shah's willingness and resilience to rise after a school dropout due to health problems.
Commenting on his background, Shah said that after finishing school, he applied to continue his university studies but was unsuccessful before starting a business by offering services in graphic design.
“Little by little, I was often attacked by migraines and that left me with a lot of sick leave and eventually poor results in the Malaysian Certificate of Education (SPM).
“For failing to accept university offers, I used my skills by offering graphic design services for T-shirts and others, but the business stopped in the middle of the road due to the low bookings.
“While waiting for another opportunity to arrive, I took the initiative to learn Korean on Youtube and did not take classes at that time because of the expensive fees.
“After six months, I made the decision to emigrate to South Korea with only RM700 in savings.
"During my 14 months there (South Korea), I lived my life working in a guest house and it was challenging because I had no choice but to speak Korean to" survive, "he said when contacted by Daily Metro.


Shah was in Korea. Photo courtesy of Siti Aishah Noor Azham

Further story, before returning home he was offered a translator and his first involvement was in last year's Winner and iKON concerts.
According to Shah, the offer was accepted after a friend proposed his name to the organizer but he still had to go through the initial screening process.
Returning to Malaysia, Shah took a month's leave before working as a graphic designer and translator at a South Korean cosmetics company based in Kuala Lumpur.
“To date, I am still accepting an offer as a translator and despite my experience, I still have to meet the requirements of the organizer, which is to submit a 'resume' for review before being short listed.
“It sounds fun but it's not easy to work with outsiders because they are so meticulous and so perfect that I need to be mentally and physically prepared.
“Usually, concerts will be held over the weekend and a few days before that, I have started working as a translator for South Korea's sound engineer and representative in Malaysia.
“So far, I have had no problems in translating but have also misunderstood when dealing with a sound engineer because he thought he was talking technical when he wanted water for thirst.
"However, the experience gained so far has been invaluable in dealing with artists and concert organizers from South Korea because in fact, I am not a K-pop fan even though it has become a frenzy of many Malaysians," he said, who plans to continue his studies in History and History.
